HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 11, 1928

DE TOCQUEVILLE
CONTEST THURSDAY
The De Tocqueville medal
contest which was scheduled
for yesterday's assembly, will
be held at the assembly on
Thursday, May 17. Due to
the nominations of A. A
Board delegates yesterday, it
was necessary to postpone the
contest for another week.
The subject of the contest
held annually in memory of
the noted French scientist,
Baron De Tocqueville, this
year will be : "The Industrial
Future of France".

FINAL JUNE WEEK
PLANS COMPLETED
Dance After Navy Game Tomorrow Evening

TENNIS TEAM TO PLAY
POSTPONED MATCHES
The tennis match scheduled
with Washington and Jefferson College for Wednesday,
May 9, was cancelled on account of heavy rain, as was
the match with University of
Maryland on May 5.
The Washington and Jefferson raqueters are on their
northern tour. If possible the
match will be played before
the Virginians return home.
The Maryland matc h,
which was called when the
visitors were leading 4 to 3 is
being awaited with interest.

421 E. 31st St.
Students at Ohio State University have petitioned the faculty to
permit them to summarily leave the
class room if the lecture being given
is dull or fails to interest. A few
days ago they were answered by a
member of the faculty. He announced himself as being decidedly
in favor of the proposition provided
that the instructor in turn should be
allowed to leave the class if the students failed to give the proper response.

A certain professor of psychology
at Northwestern University has
rather aptly remarked that it does
not pay for the modern American
undergraduate to think. He believes
that the success of a student in college depends upon his- ability to
memorize and then recite. The doctor appears to have pretty nearly
hit the nail on the head.

The Yale Daily News recently
published an editorial whimsically
commenting on the results of the
annual senior class statistical voting
which had just been held. It runs
in part: "The answers to the questionnaire are eagerly seized upon
by the public and the press as being
the most representative and carefully considered opinion of undergraduate Yale. Few newspapers in
the country have failed to hail with
delight the fact that Lindbergh is
Yale's choice as the greatest world
figure. Almost as many writers
have also pointed to the expressed
preference to a Phi Bete Key over
a major "Y" and drawn the sagacious conclusion that modern youth
is not degenerating at all." All of
which makes quite a nice reading
editorial, contains not a little truth,
and more than a little `Yale'."
*

*

*

Some ancient frosh regulations of
Harvard and Yale of nearly two
hundred years ago have lately been
uncovered. At Harvard they forbade the yearling to laugh in the
face of an upperclassman, to ask
impertinent questions, or to give
impudent answers. At Yale a different set of rules were in force.
Here the frosh were forbidden to
swear, play at dice or cards, or to
order strong drink at any tavern
within two miles of the college. The
penalty for any infraction varies
from a fine to expulsion.

HOMEWOOD

Norris and Usilton Stars of
Visitors
Tomorrow morning the Hopkins
track team will meet the Washington College cinderpathmen at
Homewood in the last dual track
meet of the Jays' season. A victory over the visitors tomorrow will
mean an undefeated season for the
Black and Blue track squad. Coach
Ridgely Edwards has been working
hard during the past week to bring
his cinderpath and field men in tip
top condition for the final dual meet
of the season and means to keep
the Black and Blue slate clean,
despite the strength of the Washington aggregation.
Last week the Washington College runners defeated Susquahanna
in a dual meet by a decisive score
of 77 to 49. The strength of the
winning team proved to be in the
hurdles, the middle-distances, and
in the field events, Susquahanna
scoring most of its points in the
long-distance runs and the dashes.
Norris, Usilton Threats

Winning seven out of nine
matches the Hopkins net team overwhelmingly defeated Delaware's
team last Tuesday in a match
almost devoid of any real struggle.
The Delaware men were completely
outclassed, succumbing extremely
readily in all but few cases to the
onslaught of their opponents.
In five of the six singles, Hopkins men emerged victors, Captain
Proctor being the only man to lose
his match. Four of the victories
were won without any difficulty in
two straight sets, while Gump
after losing the first set of his
match rallied and decisively defeated his opponent.
In the doubles, Delaware won
only one of the three matches,
Creamer and Taylor defeating
Proctor and Polan who were somewhat off their usual form.
In the singles:
Creamer, Delawlare, defeated
Proctor, Hopkins, 6-1, 6-4; Polan,
Hopkins, defeated Taylor, Delaware, 6-1, 6-3; Brockman, Hopkins, defeated Pyle, Delaware, 6-2,
7-5; Debuskey, Hopkins, defeated
Speakman, Delaware, 6-2, 7-5;
Gump, Hopkins, defeated Hoffecker, Delaware, 2-6, 6-1, 6-0; Leonard, Hopkins, defeated Moran,
Delaware, 6-2, 7-5.

TUTORING

Ominous as the Washington
stars seem, the Jays have good men
to work against them. In the one
and two mile runs, Gwinn and
Schiebel, who have been running
first and second throughout the
year, are sure of places. Wheeler
and Yellot ought to place in the
880 yard run. Lockard or Pindell
should take the hundred yard dash,
while Ness, Lockhard and Pindell
should place in the 220. Vinell,
Hershey and Scheidt should shatter Washington's hopes in the high
and low hurdles. In the field events
Garrett and Vinell look good in the
high jump and Neall and Ness in
the broad-jump. Berger and Hill
ought to give the visitors some competition in the shot-put and the discus throw. Walp, with Washington's star, Norris, as a pace-maker,
is expected to break the Hopkins
record in the javelin throw. In
the pole vault the Scheidt brothers
should take the first two places.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 11, 1928

DE TOCQUEVILLE
CONTEST THURSDAY
The De Tocqueville medal
contest which was scheduled
for yesterday's assembly, will
be held at the assembly on
Thursday, May 17. Due to
the nominations of A. A
Board delegates yesterday, it
was necessary to postpone the
contest for another week.
The subject of the contest
held annually in memory of
the noted French scientist,
Baron De Tocqueville, this
year will be : "The Industrial
Future of France".

FINAL JUNE WEEK
PLANS COMPLETED
Dance After Navy Game Tomorrow Evening

TENNIS TEAM TO PLAY
POSTPONED MATCHES
The tennis match scheduled
with Washington and Jefferson College for Wednesday,
May 9, was cancelled on account of heavy rain, as was
the match with University of
Maryland on May 5.
The Washington and Jefferson raqueters are on their
northern tour. If possible the
match will be played before
the Virginians return home.
The Maryland matc h,
which was called when the
visitors were leading 4 to 3 is
being awaited with interest.

421 E. 31st St.
Students at Ohio State University have petitioned the faculty to
permit them to summarily leave the
class room if the lecture being given
is dull or fails to interest. A few
days ago they were answered by a
member of the faculty. He announced himself as being decidedly
in favor of the proposition provided
that the instructor in turn should be
allowed to leave the class if the students failed to give the proper response.

A certain professor of psychology
at Northwestern University has
rather aptly remarked that it does
not pay for the modern American
undergraduate to think. He believes
that the success of a student in college depends upon his- ability to
memorize and then recite. The doctor appears to have pretty nearly
hit the nail on the head.

The Yale Daily News recently
published an editorial whimsically
commenting on the results of the
annual senior class statistical voting
which had just been held. It runs
in part: "The answers to the questionnaire are eagerly seized upon
by the public and the press as being
the most representative and carefully considered opinion of undergraduate Yale. Few newspapers in
the country have failed to hail with
delight the fact that Lindbergh is
Yale's choice as the greatest world
figure. Almost as many writers
have also pointed to the expressed
preference to a Phi Bete Key over
a major "Y" and drawn the sagacious conclusion that modern youth
is not degenerating at all." All of
which makes quite a nice reading
editorial, contains not a little truth,
and more than a little `Yale'."
*

*

*

Some ancient frosh regulations of
Harvard and Yale of nearly two
hundred years ago have lately been
uncovered. At Harvard they forbade the yearling to laugh in the
face of an upperclassman, to ask
impertinent questions, or to give
impudent answers. At Yale a different set of rules were in force.
Here the frosh were forbidden to
swear, play at dice or cards, or to
order strong drink at any tavern
within two miles of the college. The
penalty for any infraction varies
from a fine to expulsion.

LAST DUAL MEET TO Jay Racqueters
Beat Delaware
BE HELD TOMORROW
Unbeaten Jay Squad to Run
Washington College
TO

BE

AT

HOMEWOOD

Norris and Usilton Stars of
Visitors
Tomorrow morning the Hopkins
track team will meet the Washington College cinderpathmen at
Homewood in the last dual track
meet of the Jays' season. A victory over the visitors tomorrow will
mean an undefeated season for the
Black and Blue track squad. Coach
Ridgely Edwards has been working
hard during the past week to bring
his cinderpath and field men in tip
top condition for the final dual meet
of the season and means to keep
the Black and Blue slate clean,
despite the strength of the Washington aggregation.
Last week the Washington College runners defeated Susquahanna
in a dual meet by a decisive score
of 77 to 49. The strength of the
winning team proved to be in the
hurdles, the middle-distances, and
in the field events, Susquahanna
scoring most of its points in the
long-distance runs and the dashes.
Norris, Usilton Threats

Winning seven out of nine
matches the Hopkins net team overwhelmingly defeated Delaware's
team last Tuesday in a match
almost devoid of any real struggle.
The Delaware men were completely
outclassed, succumbing extremely
readily in all but few cases to the
onslaught of their opponents.
In five of the six singles, Hopkins men emerged victors, Captain
Proctor being the only man to lose
his match. Four of the victories
were won without any difficulty in
two straight sets, while Gump
after losing the first set of his
match rallied and decisively defeated his opponent.
In the doubles, Delaware won
only one of the three matches,
Creamer and Taylor defeating

but the orchestra has not been secured. For the other dances, with

The swimming party which was
discussed by the committee has been
abandoned because of the criticism
that too many events were being
taken off the campus. The fact that
all dances will be held indoors this
year insures against the possibility
of bad weather, as well as making
a deficit such as occurred last year
a practical impossibility. A gift of
fifty dollars from the Cotillon Club
also makes the financial status of
June Week more secure.

number was reduced to ten or fifteen at the end of the season. With
the cage on the campus this difficulty will be eliminated."

TUTORING

Ominous as the Washington
stars seem, the Jays have good men
to work against them. In the one
and two mile runs, Gwinn and
Schiebel, who have been running
first and second throughout the
year, are sure of places. Wheeler
and Yellot ought to place in the
880 yard run. Lockard or Pindell
should take the hundred yard dash,
while Ness, Lockhard and Pindell
should place in the 220. Vinell,
Hershey and Scheidt should shatter Washington's hopes in the high
and low hurdles. In the field events
Garrett and Vinell look good in the
high jump and Neall and Ness in
the broad-jump. Berger and Hill
ought to give the visitors some competition in the shot-put and the discus throw. Walp, with Washington's star, Norris, as a pace-maker,
is expected to break the Hopkins
record in the javelin throw. In
the pole vault the Scheidt brothers
should take the first two places.
